title: Does leprosy spread by just touching a leprosy infected patient? - Quora

response.answer_text: Leprosy is a contagious disease caused by ‘Mycobacterium leprae'. The truth is it is simply a mild infectious disease. It is not hereditary and cannot be caught by touch. Scientists believe it is caught through droplets of moisture passed through the air from someone who has leprosy but has not yet started treatment. It takes years, however, of living in close proximity with an untreated leprosy patient to catch the disease. Around 95 per cent of people are thought to be naturally immune to leprosy. But if you find any of these symptoms, seek medical attention immediately. This is a rare disease which can't be left untreated or unconcerned about. Pain areas: in the joints Skin: blister, loss of colour, rashes, redness, or ulcers Sensory: loss of temperature sensation, pins and needles, or reduced sensation of touch Also common: nerve injury or weight loss

About Leprosy: Leprosy is a chronic(can last for years or lifelong) infectious bacterial disease caused by Mycobacterium Leprae.It mainly affects the skin,the peripheral nerves,mucosa surfaces of the upper respiratory tract and the eyes.Even though the exact mechanism of transmission of Leprosy is not known,the most widely held belief was that the disease was transmitted by contact between cases of Leprosy and healthy persons.The possibility of transmission by the respiratory route is gaining ground more recently.Leprosy is now a curable disease.How it spreads: By airborne respiratory droplets(coughs or sneezes) and it can be cured with 6–12 months of multi-drug therapy. Early treatment avoids disability. Symptoms: Light coloured or red skin patches with reduced sensation, numbness and weakness in hands and feet. So,the answer for your question is NO. By just touching an affected person,the bacteria will not transmit into your body.

No… It is an extremely slow bacterium that is very hard to spread from person to person… Prolonged exposure to a infected person only causes leprosy… This usually happens only for household contacts…. BTW, it spreads by air by inhaling aerosol droplets from an infected person… Though the disease produces skin lesions, it does not spread by casual touch…. And within a week of starting treatment, the patient becomes noninfective to others… The remaining duration of treatment ( few months to almost a year ) is to kill all the dormant [sleeping] bacteria in the body

No, casual or even prolonged skin touch doesn't cause spread of Leprosy bacteria. Leprosy is thought to be transmitted via droplets from the nose and mouth during close prolonged contact with affected individuals, though the exact route of transmission has yet to be proven definitively.Not all individuals infected with M. leprae will go on to develop leprosy, because only 5%-10% of the population is thought to be susceptible to the infection because of immunological reasons. And it's completely curable disease now.

It's a little bit complicated so I advise you pick a browser (I use Edge a lot) and ask how is leprosy, or Hansen's disease (the preferred term) spread. Most authorities think it seems to be spread in aerosols from an infected person, i.e. coughing and sneezing. Susceptibility varies from person to person, and between ethnic groups. And actually it is not very contagious, unlike diseases such as measles in which the virus is infectious for up to 2 hours after an infected person coughs or sneezes in a room for instance. Up to 90% of non-immune persons will come down with measles just by walking through that room. Airborne infections are the worst in terms of making a lot of people sick. It's not so bad catching the common cold, but pneumonic plague, Yersinia pestis (old name Pasteurella pestis) is much deadlier than bubonic plague. Same microorganism, but spread differently. One is airborne, the other requires direct contact with exudate from a ruptured bubo, usually through a mucous membrane, because intact, unbroken skin is more resistant to infection.
